Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: PEARL: Peers Engaged As Resources for Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ongoing efforts to strengthen mathematics education in the United States have emphasized the need for students to engage and persevere with meaningful and challenging mathematics problems, and to take active and collaborative roles in problem solving. Teachers often use small group instruction to work toward these goals: small group work occurs in 70% of middle grades mathematics classrooms at least once a week, and on average, accounts for 25% of instructional time in middle grades mathematics classes. Yet effective group work can prove challenging for middle school teachers. Students quickly disengage from difficult tasks and their peer interactions often undermine productive collaborations. The PEARL project brings an interdisciplinary team to: (1) study small group work; (2) understand the challenges involved in promoting successful small groups; and (3) determine ways to help teachers deliver on the promise of group work. The PEARL study involves a carefully sequenced set of research phases that include classroom observations, interviews and surveys with teachers and students regarding mathematics small group work in both naturalistic settings and experimental conditions in order to develop and test both a framework for understanding small group learning environments and strategies to help teachers support successful group work. Results of the study will inform teacher preparation and ongoing education, mathematics teaching practice, and educational research.

The Principles and Standards for School Mathematics and the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics emphasize the critical role of students' deep engagement with meaningful mathematical content with their peers to support development of mathematical understanding. Mathematics classrooms are often structured to meet these goals by arranging students in small group learning environments expected to create peer-to-peer interactions that promote conceptual learning, mathematical communication, and use of peers as learning resources. Effective group work depends on tasks that are cognitively challenging and appropriate for group efforts, group discourse that promotes engagement and meaning making, and peer relational processes that support collaboration and learning. An interdisciplinary team will study small group work in middle grades mathematics classrooms, integrating three conceptual frameworks - Mathematics Task, Mathematics Discourse Matrix, and Peer Cultures of Effort and Achievement - to understand the challenges involved in promoting successful small group learning environments, and to determine ways to help teachers deliver on the promise of group work. The results of a series of design cycles in field settings will produce theoretically derived and empirically based insights in the service of experimental testing of an integrated framework that links research and practice. This framework, and the research design and tools, can stimulate further interdisciplinary study among mathematics educators and educational psychologists in terms of how teachers can coordinate tasks, discourse, and peer cultures in pursuit of successful small group work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

The project "Peers Engaged as Resources for Learning Mathematics (PEARL)" investigated small group learning environments in middle and high school mathematics classrooms. The first goal of PEARL was to develop a framework that integrates the mathematical work, the peer-to-peer discourse, and the social dynamics that occur in student groups in classrooms. Using this framework, the project's research studies first investigated the strategies mathematics teachers use to manage small group work, and then developed and studied instructional resources and a professional development program designed to promote effective teaching strategies and curricular supports for students to engage in high-functioning group work in learning mathematics.

The PEARL framework, professional development, and lesson resources center on our definition that high-functioning group work occurs when students are individually engaged and collegially communicating, seeking and receiving the help they need from one another, to explain, justify, and make meaning of mathematical ideas. Our work to put this definition into practice and study the professional learning, teaching strategies, and student activities that support it took place between 2014 and 2020. During this time PEARL partnered with 15 teachers in three school districts teaching students ranging from grades 6 to 10 who participated in professional development, co-developed lessons, and provided opportunities for the project's research studies in their classrooms.

Intellectual Merit

The project's research used multiple methods. We interviewed teachers and conducted focus group interviews with students to learn their perspectives on small group work in mathematics classrooms. We engaged in consultation meetings with teachers to plan lessons for small-group instruction. We observed classroom lessons and audiorecorded or videorecorded the teacher and small groups of students as they worked, to examine teaching strategies and small group functioning. We surveyed students to understand their perceptions of working in small groups to learn mathematics. Our initial studies led to creation of a professional development program that we provided to support teachers, and practical sets of teacher and student supports that we incorporated into lesson plans and student materials for instruction. Analyses from later studies showed that teachers' instruction, following engagement in PEARL professional development and using the enhanced PEARL lesson plans and student materials, exhibited more positive talk with students as they supported their work in groups and transitioned them into and out of group work. This finding reflects positive appraisals of how well teachers are achieving their instructional goals and it is associated with student engagement. Students' reports of their small group functioning in these PEARL lessons indicated stronger engagement with the mathematics demands of the tasks assigned to groups and greater focus while working in groups.  

Broader Impacts

Informed by its research studies, the project's development efforts have produced professional learning opportunities for teachers and instructional resources for teachers and students to promote higher functioning group work in secondary mathematics classrooms. The PEARL framework offers teachers a way to understand and shape group work in their classrooms that combines challenging mathematics tasks, supportive and collaborative peer social dynamics, and productive student-to-student discourse for learning. The PEARL professional development program provides learning activities for teachers to make use of these frameworks and to become familiar with the instructional resources for teachers and students that are built into PEARL lessons. Teachers learn to use a practical set of six teaching moves (Transitioning In, Circulating, Checking In, Checking Out, Taking Stock, and Transitioning Out) that can structure their enactment of the lesson plans. Students are guided to work effectively using four supports for group work (Do This First!, Mathematically Meaningful Roles, Help Seeking and Help Providing Prompts, and Group Products) which are built into student materials. Dissemination of research and development results through project publications and presentations at local, national, and international conferences has enhanced teachers', teacher leaders', and teacher educators' understanding of how to promote high-functioning group work for mathematics learning.
